<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Revenue generated in Europe increased by &#128;9.4&nbsp;million, or 24.7%, in the year ended December&nbsp;31,
	2014 compared to the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2013, mainly as a result of increased revenue in our Materialise Manufacturing and Materialise Software segments. Revenue generated throughout the Americas increased by &#128;0.7&nbsp;million, or
	2.7%, in the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014 compared to the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2013, primarily as a result of increased revenue in our Materialise Software segment. Revenue generated in Asia increased by &#128;2.6&nbsp;million, or
	43.5%, in the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014 compared to the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2013, primarily boosted by the increased revenue in our Materialise Software segment.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Revenue from our Materialise Software segment increased from &#128;13.4&nbsp;million in the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2013 to
	&#128;18.1&nbsp;million in the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014, which represented an increase of &#128;4.7&nbsp;million, or 34.7%. This increase was mainly due to increases of sales of new software licenses (new perpetual licenses and first time
	annual licenses) and sales to OEMs, which increased by 47.7% and 53.8%, respectively, from the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2013 to the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014. Over the same period, our recurring software related revenue (maintenance
	contracts and renewals of annual licenses) increased by 23.3% and our service revenues increased by 29.8%. In our Materialise Software segment, we consider both our first time annual license sales and our new perpetual license sales as important
	sources of potential follow on revenue. Our first time annual licenses create potential for renewals, while our perpetual licenses, which are in many instances sold together with the sale of a 3D printer by a manufacturer, not only create potential
	for future maintenance revenue but are also an important source for follow on sales of additional software modules to the customer. These follow on sales are considered new software sales.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Revenue from our Materialise Medical segment increased from &#128;28.0&nbsp;million in the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2013 to
	&#128;30.0&nbsp;million in the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014, representing an increase of &#128;2.0&nbsp;million, or 7.3%. Revenue from clinical services (which is derived from the sale of clinical devices, which we bring to the market in
	combination with software solutions and engineering services) increased by 2.5%, while revenue from the sale of medical software and related services increased by 23.3%. Revenue from new medical software licenses (new perpetual licenses and first
	time annual licenses) and related services increased by 1.4%, while our recurring medical software related revenue (maintenance contracts and renewals of annual licenses) increased by 27.3%. Following the acquisition of OrthoView in the fourth
	quarter of 2014, an additional &#128;0.9&nbsp;million revenue was added to the Materialise Medical segment. Our medical software is modular, with some modules licensed out as a perpetual license which include a maintenance scheme, while the newer
	modules are licensed on an annual basis. As of April 2014, we have adopted a new model, whereby, except for research and academic centers, our medical software will only be offered through time-based licenses (and no longer on a perpetual basis).
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Revenue from our Materialise Manufacturing segment increased from &#128;27.2&nbsp;million in the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2013 to
	&#128;33.2&nbsp;million in the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014, representing an increase of &#128;6.0&nbsp;million, or 22.0%. We increased the number of 3D printers that we operated from 98 3D printers and five vacuum casting machines at
	December&nbsp;31, 2013 to 116 3D printers and six vacuum casting machines at December&nbsp;31, 2014.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Two of our potential growth
	businesses (i.materialise and Rapid Fit) are part of our Materialise Manufacturing segment. Both businesses are currently in a pre-profitability investment phase, which adversely impacts overall profit for the segment. Revenue from our Materialise
	Manufacturing segment excluding i.materialise and RapidFit (which we sometimes refer to as our &#147;additive manufacturing solutions&#148; business) increased from &#128;24.4&nbsp;million in the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2013 to
	&#128;28.1&nbsp;million in the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014, representing an increase of &#128;3.7&nbsp;million, or 15.2%. Our additive manufacturing solutions business sold, in the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2013 as well as in the same
	period in 2014, a wide variety of products (most of which are uniquely customized), based on a wide variety of materials and produced by means of multiple 3D printing technologies. In the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014, our additive manufacturing
	solutions business experienced stronger growth in its manufacturing of end parts than in its prototyping activities, with 26.1% and 12.9% growth, respectively.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	During the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014, and across our various segments, 32.3% of our revenue was derived from 3D Printing and Medical
	software licenses and related services, as compared to 29.2% in the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2013, 40.6% of our revenues was derived from the sale of printed industrial and consumer products, as compared to 39.5% in the year ended
	December&nbsp;31, 2013, and 27.1% of our revenues was derived from the sale of medical devices (guides as well as implants) that were brought to the market together with complex software planning solutions, including royalties and other fees, as
	compared to 31.3% in the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2013.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	- 58 -
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage61"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D120629D20F_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
	Cost of sales.
</I>
	Cost of sales was &#128;32.4&nbsp;million in the year ended
	December&nbsp;31, 2014 compared to &#128;27.2&nbsp;million in the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2013, an increase of &#128;5.2&nbsp;million, or 19.2%. This increase in cost of sales was primarily attributable to increased salaries, which increased by
	&#128;3.4&nbsp;million from the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2013. The remaining increase was mainly attributable to increases in raw materials and external subcontracting services, which increased by &#128;1.1&nbsp;million as compared to the year
	ended December&nbsp;31, 2013.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
	Gross profit.
</I>
	As a result of the relatively lower revenue growth in the Medical segment, the overall
	gross profit margin (our gross profit divided by our revenue) decreased slightly to 60.2% in the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014 from 60.4% in the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2013, a decrease of 0.2%. For the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014,
	gross profit of &#128;49.0&nbsp;million reflected growth of 17.9% compared to the prior year.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
	Research and development expenses.
</I>
	Research and development expenses were &#128;15.1&nbsp;million in the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014 compared to &#128;10.6&nbsp;million in the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2013, an increase of &#128;4.5&nbsp;million, or 42.4%. This increase
	in research and development expenses was primarily attributable to an increased investment in medical research projects, which increased by &#128;2.4&nbsp;million, and software development, which increased by &#128;1.4&nbsp;million, as compared to
	the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2013.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
	Sales and marketing expenses.
</I>
	Sales and marketing expenses increased from
	&#128;22.4&nbsp;million in the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2013 to &#128;27.5&nbsp;million in the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2013, an increase of &#128;5.2&nbsp;million, or 23.2%. This increase was primarily attributable to an increase in
	headcount in connection with our efforts to increase our sales volume, resulting in increased payroll expenses related to sales and marketing expenses.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
	General and administrative expenses.
</I>
	General and administrative expenses were &#128;11.6&nbsp;million in the year ended
	December&nbsp;31, 2014 compared to &#128;8.7&nbsp;million in the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2013, an increase of &#128;3.0&nbsp;million, or 34.6%. This reflects increased investments in corporate functions such as human resources and finance, as
	well as increased legal, accounting and other services mainly in connection with the preparation for our initial public offering as well as our operating as a public company.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
	Other operating income.
</I>
	Other operating income increased from &#128;5.1&nbsp;million in the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2013 to
	&#128;6.0&nbsp;million in the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014. This increase in other operating income was primarily attributable to an increase in funding for research and development projects of &#128;0.4 million. In the year ended
	December&nbsp;31, 2014, &#128;3.6&nbsp;million out of the &#128;5.7&nbsp;million other operating income was a release of grant income directly related to the level of research and development effort, consisting of withholding tax exemptions for
	qualifying researchers and partial funding of research and development contracts, as compared to &#128;3.2&nbsp;million in the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2013.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
	Financial expenses
</I>
	. Financial expenses decreased from &#128;1.3&nbsp;million in the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2013 to
	&#128;1.2&nbsp;million in the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014, a slight decrease of &#128;0.1 million.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
	Financial income
</I>
	.
	Financial income increased from &#128;0.3&nbsp;million in the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2013 to &#128;3.2&nbsp;million in the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014, primarily due to foreign exchange gain on the portion of the initial public offering
	proceeds held U.S. dollars.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
	Income taxes
</I>
	. Income taxes in the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014 remained small mainly due to
	research and development tax credits and patent income deduction (which is a favorable tax regime for income derived from patents).
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
	Net profit
</I>
	. As a result of the factors described above, net profit was &#128;1.9&nbsp;million in the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014
	compared to a net profit of &#128;3.4&nbsp;million in the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2013, a decrease of &#128;1.5 million.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
	EBITDA.
</I>
	As a result of the factors described above, our consolidated EBITDA decreased from &#128;7.6&nbsp;million in the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2013 to &#128;4.9&nbsp;million in the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014, a decrease of
	&#128;2.7&nbsp;million, or 35.7%, and our total segment EBITDA decreased from &#128;11.1&nbsp;million in the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2013 to &#128;10.6&nbsp;million in the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014, a decrease of &#128;0.5&nbsp;million,
	or 4.4%.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Our Materialise Software segment&#146;s EBITDA increased from &#128;5.1&nbsp;million in the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2013,
	to &#128;6.6&nbsp;million in the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014, an increase of &#128;1.4&nbsp;million, or 28.1%. As a result of a 39.0% increase in sales and marketing and research and development expenses, this segment&#146;s EBITDA margin (the
	segment&#146;s EBITDA divided by the segment&#146;s revenue) decreased from 38.3% for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2013 to 36.4% in the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	- 59 -
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage62"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D120629D20F_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Our Materialise Medical segment&#146;s EBITDA decreased from &#128;5.0&nbsp;million in the year
	ended December&nbsp;31, 2013 to &#128;2.9&nbsp;million in the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014. The segment&#146;s EBITDA margin decreased from 17.8% in the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2013 to 9.7% in the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014, which
	was mainly the result of an 18.0% increase in sales and marketing and research and development expenses.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Our Materialise Manufacturing
	segment&#146;s EBITDA increased from &#128;1.0&nbsp;million in the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2013 to &#128;1.1&nbsp;million in the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014. The EBITDA of our &#147;additive manufacturing solutions&#148; business (which
	excludes i.materialise and RapidFit) increased from &#128;3.5&nbsp;million in the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2013 to &#128; 4.0&nbsp;million in the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014, resulting in relatively stable EBITDA margins of 14.5% in the
	year ended December&nbsp;31, 2013 and 14.4% in the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014. This increase in EBITDA was the result of an increased capacity in 2014 as compared to 2013.
</P>
<EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>
<A NAME="FIS_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE_17"></A>

<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:18PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<EFX_LIQUIDITY_CAPITAL>
<A NAME="FIS_LIQUIDITY_CAPITAL"></A>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="4%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
<B>
	B.
</B>
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<B>
	Liquidity and Capital Resources
</B>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Prior to our initial public offering, we historically
	funded our operations principally from cash generated from operations and borrowings. On June&nbsp;30, 2014, we completed our initial public offering of 8,000,000 ADSs at a price of $12.00 per ADS, and received net proceeds of approximately $88.3
	million. As we continue to grow our business, we envision funding our operations through multiple sources, including the remaining proceeds from our initial public offering, future earnings and cash flow from operations and borrowings.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	We expect our main uses of cash in the future will be funding our business operations and capital expenditures, as in the past. We believe
	that we will have sufficient liquidity to satisfy the operating requirements of our business through the next 12&nbsp;months.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Our
	liquidity plans are subject to a number of risks and uncertainties, including those described in the section of this annual report titled &#147;Item 3. Key Information&#151;D. Risk Factors,&#148; some of which are outside of our control.
	Macro-economic conditions could hinder our business plans, which could, in turn, adversely affect our financing strategy.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	- 60 -
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage63"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D120629D20F_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>
<A NAME="FIS_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE_18"></A>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
<I>
	Cash Flows
</I>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">

	December&nbsp;31, 2015, 2014 and 2013.

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
	Comparison of Year Ended December&nbsp;31, 2015 and 2014
</I>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Net cash flow from operating activities was &#128;2.4&nbsp;million in the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015 compared to &#128;4.8&nbsp;million
	in the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014, a decrease of &#128;2.4&nbsp;million, or 50.0%. The decrease in cash flow from operating activities was primarily the result of a lower EBITDA (- &#128;2.0 million).
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Net cash flow used in investing activities was &#128;2.8&nbsp;million in the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015 compared to
	&#128;31.2&nbsp;million in the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014, a decrease of &#128;28.4&nbsp;million, or 91.0%. The decrease in cash flow used in investing activities was primarily the lower level of acquisitions during 2015 compared to 2014.
	During 2015, we acquired Cenat BVBA, (&#128; 1.6 million) compared to e-prototypy and OrthoView Holdings Limited in 2014 (&#128;10.4 million). In addition, during 2015, our investments in held-to-maturity investments (&#128;10.0 million) were repaid
	in full.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Net cash flow used in financing activities was &#128;1.8&nbsp;million in the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015 compared to net
	cash flow from financing activities of &#128;62.1&nbsp;million in the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014, a decrease of &#128;63.9&nbsp;million, or 102.9%. The decrease in cash flow used in financing activities was primarily related to the receipt of
	the net proceeds from our initial public offering in 2014 (&#128;64.2 million) and our not conducting comparable capital increases in 2015.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
	Comparison
	of Year Ended December&nbsp;31, 2014 and 2013
</I>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Net cash flow from operating activities was &#128;4.8&nbsp;million in the year ended
	December&nbsp;31, 2014 compared to &#128;8.9&nbsp;million in the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2013, a decrease of &#128;4.1&nbsp;million, or 45.5%. The decrease in cash flow from operating activities was primarily the result of a lower EBITDA and a
	net increase in working capital, resulting from an increase of &#128;6.0&nbsp;million in trade receivable. The latter was the result of a &#128;1&nbsp;million increase relating to acquisitions made in the course of the year and the substantial
	increase in revenue realized during the fourth quarter of 2014 compared to the previous year.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Net cash flow used in investing activities
	was &#128;31.2&nbsp;million in the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014 compared to &#128;3.3&nbsp;million in the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2013, an increase of &#128;27.9&nbsp;million, or 846.8%. The increase in cash flow used in investing
	activities was primarily the result of the acquisitions of e-prototypy and OrthoView Holdings Limited (&#128;10.4 million), investment of unused proceeds from our initial public offering in held-to-maturity investments (&#128;10.0 million) and
	investment in machines and equipment (&#128;10.5 million).
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Net cash flow used in financing activities was &#128;62.1&nbsp;million in the
	year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014 compared to &#128;0.7&nbsp;million in the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2013, an increase of &#128;61.4&nbsp;million, or 8,413%. The increase in cash flow used in financing activities was primarily related to the
	receipt of the net proceeds from our initial public offering (&#128;64.2 million).
</P>

<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D120629D20F_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
<I>
	Indebtedness
</I>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	As of December&nbsp;31, 2015, we had long-term loans and borrowings in the total amount of &#128;21.1&nbsp;million, with fixed interest rates
	varying from 0% to 5.40%. These loans include secured bank loans used to finance the construction of office and production facilities and loans and finance leases with Ailanthus NV, a related party.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The following table sets forth our principal indebtedness as of the dates indicated:
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:12PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>

<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="4%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	(1)
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	Consists of loans that mature in October 2016 and March 2020.
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
	&#128;5.0&nbsp;million secured bank loan
</I>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	This bank loan has been used to finance the construction of a portion of a portion of our office and production building in Leuven .
	The loan term commenced on December&nbsp;23, 2011 and was completely drawn at &#128;5,000,000 as of June&nbsp;30, 2012. The loan matures on June&nbsp;30, 2027. The loan bears a fixed interest rate of 4.61% with monthly fixed installments as from
	July&nbsp;1, 2012. This bank loan is secured with a mortgage on the building.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
	&#128;2.5&nbsp;million bank loan
</I>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	This bank loan has been used to finance our Polish operations. The loan term commenced on October&nbsp;22, 2015 and is repaid in 60 fixed
	monthly payments. The loan bears a fixed interest rate of 1.36%.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
	&#128;2.0&nbsp;million secured bank loan
</I>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	This bank loan has been used to finance the construction of a portion of our office and production building in Leuven. The loan term commenced
	on December&nbsp;1, 2005 with a maturity of 15 years. The loan bears a fixed interest rate of 4.43% with monthly fixed installments. This bank loan is secured with a mortgage on the building.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	- 62 -
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage65"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D120629D20F_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
	&#128;1.8&nbsp;million secured bank loan
</I>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	This bank loan has been used to finance the construction of an office in the Czech Republic. The loan term commenced on November&nbsp;1, 2008
	with a maturity of 14 years. The loan bears a fixed interest rate of 5.40% with monthly fixed installments. This bank loan is secured with a mortgage on the building.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
	&#128;1.6&nbsp;million investment loan
</I>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	This loan was contracted to finance the operations of Materialise USA and has a term of seven years. The loan bears a fixed interest rate at
	1.52% and payments are due each trimester.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
	&#128;1.0&nbsp;million convertible bond loan
</I>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	We issued on October&nbsp;28, 2013 1,000 convertible bonds to a related party for a total amount of &#128;1.0 million. The bonds have been
	fully subscribed by a member of our senior management and his spouse. The bonds have a maturity of seven years, bear an annual interest rate of 3.7% and are convertible after December&nbsp;31, 2016 until maturity, into ordinary shares at a
	conversion price of &#128;1.97&nbsp;per share. Upon initial recognition, an amount of &#128;0.1&nbsp;million was recognized in consolidated reserves, reflecting the fair value of the conversion option. For additional information, see
	&#147;Description of Share Capital&#151;Share Capital.&#148;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
	&#128;1.0&nbsp;million straight loan
</I>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	This bank loan was contracted to finance the operations of RapidFit NV. The loan bears a fixed interest rate of 1.79% with fixed installments.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
	&#128;0.9&nbsp;million investment loan
</I>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	This loan was contracted to finance our Polish operations and has a term of seven years. The loan bears a fixed interest rate of 1.12% and
	payments are due monthly.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
	&#128;0.6&nbsp;million bank loan
</I>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	This bank loan was contracted in order to finance the acquisition of machines. The loan bears a fixed interest rate of 1.96% with fixed
	installments.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
	&#128;0.5&nbsp;million secured bank loan
</I>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	This bank loan has been used to finance the purchase of a 3D printing machine. The loan term commenced on December&nbsp;1, 2013 with a term of
	five years. The loan bears a fixed interest rate of 1.78% with monthly fixed installments and is secured by the 3D printing machine.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
	Interest-free
	loans
</I>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	We have several interest-free loans with a total outstanding nominal amount of &#128;0.9 million. The interest-free loans have
	been initially measured at fair value, which is the present value of the future installments with a discount rate of 3.04%. The maturities of the loans are in October 2016 and March 2020 and have either monthly or quarterly installments. The
	carrying values at December&nbsp;31, 2015, 2014 and 2013 were &#128;0.9&nbsp;million, &#128;1.7&nbsp;million and &#128;2.1&nbsp;million, respectively. The difference between the carrying value and the nominal value was recognized as financial income
	over the loan period. The loans have been granted by either government organizations or business partners.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
	Loans with related party
</I>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	We have entered into a loan agreement, with a fixed interest rate of 4.23%, with Ailanthus NV, which is a related party and shareholder, for
	the financing of an office building in France. For additional information, see &#147;Certain Relationships and Related Party Transactions.&#148;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	- 63 -

<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D120629D20F_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	For additional information regarding our loans and borrowings, see Note 13 to our audited
	consolidated financial statements.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
<I>
	Material Unused Sources of Liquidity
</I>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Our cash and cash equivalents as of December&nbsp;31, 2015, 2014 and 2013 were &#128;50.7&nbsp;million, &#128;51.0&nbsp;million and
	&#128;12.6&nbsp;million, respectively. Our unused lines of credit as of December&nbsp;31, 2015, 2014 and 2013 were &#128;4.4&nbsp;million, &#128;4.3&nbsp;million and &#128;4.0&nbsp;million, respectively, and primarily consisted of straight loans.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
<I>
	Transfers from Subsidiaries
</I>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The amount of dividends payable by our subsidiaries to us is subject to, among other restrictions, general limitations imposed by the corporate
	laws, capital transfer restrictions and exchange control restrictions of the respective jurisdictions where those subsidiaries are organized and operate. For example, China has very specific approval regulations for all capital transfers to or from
	the country and certain capital transfers to and from Ukraine are subject to obtaining a specific permit. Dividends paid to us by certain of our subsidiaries may also be subject to withholding taxes in certain jurisdictions. Of our cash and cash
	equivalents held outside of Belgium as of December&nbsp;31, 2015, 2014 and 2013, the amount of cash that would have been subject to withholding taxes if transferred to us by way of dividends and the amount of cash that could not have been
	transferred by law, or the transfer of which would have been subject to prior approval that was beyond our control, was in each case immaterial.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:18PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>

<TR>
<TD WIDTH="4%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
<B>
	C.
</B>

<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<B>
	Research and Development, Patents and Licenses
</B>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	For the years ended December&nbsp;31,
	2015, 2014 and 2013, our research and development expenses were &#128;18.2&nbsp;million, &#128;15.1&nbsp;million and &#128;10.6&nbsp;million, respectively, and were 17.8%, 18.6% and 15.4% of our revenue, respectively. For more information regarding
	our research and development program, see &#147;Item 4. Information on the Company&#151;B. Business Overview&#151;Research and Development.&#148;
</P>

<TD VALIGN="TOP">

</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM">

<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM" ALIGN="CENTER">
	48
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM">

	Executive Vice President
</TD>

<TR STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT">
<TD VALIGN="TOP">
	Alfinco BVBA, represented by Johan Albrecht
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM" ALIGN="CENTER">

	Chief Financial Officer

</EFX_NAME_AND_TITLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Each of our current directors was appointed at the 2015 annual general meeting of shareholders. Three of our
	previous directors, Guy Weyns, Ailanthus NV, represented by Hilde Ingelaere, and Sniper Investments NV, represented by Bart Luyten resigned at the 2015 annual general meeting of shareholders. The term of the directorship of each member of our board
	of directors will expire at the 2016 annual general meeting of shareholders. The business address of the members of our board of directors is the same as our business address: Technologielaan 15, 3001 Leuven, Belgium. Our board of directors has
	determined that three members of our board of directors, J&uuml;rgen Ingels, Godelieve Verplancke and A Tre C CVOA, represented by Johan De Lille are independent under Belgian law and the NASDAQ Stock Market listing requirements.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The following is a brief summary of the business experience of the current members of our board of directors:
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
<I>
	Wilfried Vancraen
</I>
</B>
<I>
	.
</I>
	Wilfried Vancraen has served as one of our directors and as our Chief Executive Officer since founding
	our company in July 1990. Mr.&nbsp;Vancraen previously worked as a research engineer and consultant at the Research Institute of the Belgian Metalworking Industry, where he was introduced to 3D printing. Passionate about this new technology and firm
	in his belief that it could help create a better and healthier world, he founded Materialise in July 1990. Mr.&nbsp;Vancraen holds several patents related to the technical and medical applications of 3D printing and remains committed to using the
	technology to make positive changes in people&#146;s lives. In recent years, Mr.&nbsp;Vancraen has been awarded the RTAM/SME Industry Achievement Award, the highest honor in the 3D printing industry, has been selected as the most influential person
	in additive manufacturing by industry professionals and TCT Magazine, and has been listed one of the five leading players in his sector by the Financial Times. He is also the recipient of a 2013 Visionaries! award from the Museum of Art and Design
	in New York. Mr.&nbsp;Vancraen holds a Master of Science in Electro-Mechanical Engineering and a Masters in Business Administration from KULeuven.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
<I>
	Peter Leys
</I>
</B>
<I>
	.
</I>
	Peter Leys has served as one of our directors and as our Executive Chairman since 2013. Previously, from 1990
	to 2013, Mr.&nbsp;Leys was at the Brussels office of Baker&nbsp;&amp; McKenzie CVBA, where he focused on mergers and acquisitions, and capital markets. Mr.&nbsp;Leys became an international partner of Baker&nbsp;&amp; McKenzie CVBA in 1998 and was
	appointed co-head of its Brussels office&#146;s corporate finance practice group in 2009. As an attorney, Mr.&nbsp;Leys has advised Materialise since 1997 and has assisted the company on most of its milestone corporate and commercial transactions.
	In 2012, Mr.&nbsp;Leys, who has been mentioned numerous times as a leading corporate lawyer in Chambers, Legal 500 and IFLR 1000, received the International Law Office &#147;Client&#146;s Choice Award&#148; for M&amp;A in Belgium. Mr.&nbsp;Leys is a
	Fulbright fellow and lectures a mergers and acquisitions contract design course at the KULeuven. Mr.&nbsp;Leys holds a Candidacy Degree in Philosophy from KULeuven and Master of Law degrees from KULeuven and the University of Georgia.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	- 66 -
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage69"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D120629D20F_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
<I>
	Johan De Lille
</I>
</B>
<I>
	.
</I>
	Johan De Lille has represented A Tre C CVOA as one of our
	directors since July 2006, and A Tre C CVOA has been an independent director of Materialise since 2006. Mr.&nbsp;De Lille started his professional career as an auditor at Arthur Andersen LLP in 1988. In 1994, he became Vice President&nbsp;&amp;
	Group Controller of Ackermans&nbsp;&amp; van Haaren NV, a Belgian public holding company. In 1999, he became Chief Financial Officer of Easdaq/Nasdaq Europe and took on the role of Chief Financial Officer of Option NV, a Belgian public technology
	company, in 2001. Mr.&nbsp;De Lille joined Delhaize Group, a Belgian public company, as Vice President&nbsp;&amp; Controller in September 2002, and later became Chief Internal Auditor of the Delhaize Group in August 2006, and Chief Financial Officer
	of Delhaize Belgium in January 2009. Since 2013, Mr.&nbsp;De Lille has acted as Chief Financial&nbsp;&amp; Information Officer of BMT Group, an industrial family owned holding company active in high-precision machining. Mr.&nbsp;De Lille serves as
	an independent director on the board of directors of Boma NV, a Belgian private company specializing in cleaning products. In 1988, Mr.&nbsp;De Lille was the award winner for the best final paper of the Department of Economics from KULeuven. In
	2010, he received the CFO Magazine Award for the Best Finance Team of the year for Working Capital in Belgium. Mr.&nbsp;De Lille holds a Masters degree in Economics, with a major in Econometrics and Mathematical Economics, from KULeuven.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
<I>
	Marcel Demeulenaere
</I>
</B>
<I>
	.
</I>
	Marcel Demeulenaere has served as one of our directors since 1999. Mr.&nbsp;Demeulenaere started his
	career with the Central Bank of the Belgian Congo. In 1957, Mr.&nbsp;Demeulenaere was hired by International Business Machines Corporation, or IBM, to help introduce the first computers in Belgium. Mr.&nbsp;Demeulenaere&#146;s roles at IBM included
	Director of Marketing and Services for Belgium and Luxembourg, Director of Industry Marketing, and Director of Human Resources where he was responsible for the reorganization and streamlining of the technical department. From 1985 to 1990,
	Mr.&nbsp;Demeulenaere served on the board of directors for Assubel, a medical insurance company, and later Partena, the surviving entity after a series of mergers. After his retirement from IBM Mr.&nbsp;Demeulenaere became advisor to the General
	Manager of KULeuven and created the first incubator for spin-offs. Mr.&nbsp;Demeulenaere holds a Masters degree in Marketing and Finance from KULeuven.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
<I>
	Hilde Ingelaere
</I>
</B>
<I>
	.
</I>
	Hilde Ingelaere has served as one of our directors since December 1997 (first as representative of
	Ailanthus NV and in her individual capacity since June 2015) and has been our Executive Vice President since January 2011. Since joining our company in 1990, Ms.&nbsp;Ingelaere has managed several staff departments, including the human resources,
	finance and legal departments. Ms.&nbsp;Ingelaere currently serves as Executive Vice President of our Materialise Medical segment. Prior to joining our company, from 1989 to 1992, Ms.&nbsp;Ingelaere was a business analyst with Plant Genetic Systems.
	From 1986 to 1989, Ms.&nbsp;Ingelaere was at Bristol Myers Squib where she focused on cardiovascular clinical research. Ms.&nbsp;Ingelaere holds a Masters in Bioengineering from KULeuven, where she focused on Biotechnology, and a Masters in Business
	Administration from KULeuven.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
<I>
	Pol Ingelaere
</I>
</B>
<I>
	.
</I>
	Pol Ingelaere has served as one of our directors since 2011.
	Mr.&nbsp;Ingelaere has been involved for many years in education and the sciences, teaching physics, chemistry and biology to final grade college students in Belgium. In 1981 Mr.&nbsp;Ingelaere was appointed as an inspector for all science teachers
	in West Flanders, Belgium. Mr.&nbsp;Ingelaere has been an active member of a number of educational commissions. Mr.&nbsp;Ingelaere holds a Masters degree in Biology from the University of Ghent and an International Certificate in Human Ecology from
	the Free University of Brussels.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
<I>
	J&uuml;rgen Ingels
</I>
</B>
	. J&uuml;rgen Ingels has served as one of our independent directors
	since November 2013. Mr.&nbsp;Ingels is Founder and Managing Partner of SmartFin Capital, a growth stage private equity fund that was set up in December 2014. In October 2014, Mr.&nbsp;Ingels sold Clear2Pay NV/S.A., a global innovative payments
	software technology company he founded in 2001, to FIS Global. The clients of Clear2Pay include global and major regional financial institutions such as ING Group, Banco Santander, S.A., Cr&eacute;dit Agricole S.A., BNP Paribas, The U.S. Federal
	Reserve, Royal Bank of Scotland, The People&#146;s Bank of China (PBOC). In 2011, Mr.&nbsp;Ingels co-founded NGdata, Inc., a global big data technology company. Mr.&nbsp;Ingels started his career in private equity in 1997 at Dexia NV/S.A., where his
	role was focused on investing in technology companies. Mr.&nbsp;Ingels currently serves as a director on the board of directors for UnifiedPost NV, D square NV, Guardsquare NV, Projective NV, Itineris NV and Glue NV. Mr.&nbsp;Ingels holds a Masters
	degree in Business Administration and a Masters degree in Political and Social Sciences from the University of Antwerp.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
<I>
	Jos Vander
	Sloten
</I>
</B>
<I>
	.
</I>
	Jos Vander Sloten has served as one of our directors since January 2007. Mr.&nbsp;Vander Sloten is a full professor at the Faculty of Engineering Science, KULeuven and chaired the Division of Biomechanics for two terms from
	2006 to 2014. He now chairs the Leuven Medical Technology Centre (L-MTC), which he founded in 2008. Mr.&nbsp;Vander Sloten teaches engineering mechanics, problem solving and engineering design, computer integrated surgery systems, and medical device
	design including regulatory affairs. From 2006 to 2012, he served as program director of the Master in Biomedical Engineering at KULeuven. His research interests are computer applications in musculoskeletal biomechanics and computer integrated
	surgery, on which he authored more than 160 journal papers. Mr.&nbsp;Vander Sloten is a Founding Fellow of the European Alliance for Medical and Biological Engineering and Science, where he previously served as president in 2006, president-elect in
	2005 and secretary-general from 2003 to 2004. In 2015, he was elected as a member of the International Academy for Medical and Biological Engineering. Mr.&nbsp;Vander Sloten holds a Masters degree in Mechanical Engineering and a PhD in Mechanical
	Engineering &#150; Biomedical Engineering from KULeuven.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	- 67 -
</P>

	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
<I>
	Godelieve Verplancke
</I>
</B>
	. Godelieve Verplancke has served as one of our independent
	directors since June 2015.&nbsp;Ms.&nbsp;Verplancke began her career in 1984 with The Beecham Group (now part of GlaxoSmithKline), and has since held key management positions with Merck&nbsp;&amp; Co., as well as Bristol-Myers Squibb, where she
	served as Managing Director, leading their Belgian/GDL subsidiary, until 2012.&nbsp;Ms.&nbsp;Verplancke has also served as a board member for Brussels-based Europe Hospitals, the Imelda Hospital in Bonheiden, the Euronext fund, Quest for Growth and
	the Stichting tegen Kanker. She is also the founder and managing director of Qaly@Beersel, an elderly care center in Belgium. In addition to being a medical doctor (MD &#150; KULeuven), Ms.&nbsp;Verplancke holds a postgraduate degree in Economics
	and a Master in Business Administration from the University of Antwerp.&nbsp;She has also completed courses at INSEAD, CEDEP, Columbia University and the Vlerick Business School, and is a certified Executive Coach (PCC).
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The following is a brief summary of the business experience of our senior management:
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
<I>
	Johan Pauwels
</I>
</B>
	. Johan Pauwels has served as an Executive Vice President of our company since January 2011 and has been with our
	company since our founding. In 1990, Mr.&nbsp;Pauwels completed his Master&#146;s thesis on stereolithography on the very first 3D printing machine at Materialise. After graduating in 1991, Mr.&nbsp;Pauwels stayed on with our company, focusing on
	software development to support our 3D printing services. Throughout his career with our company, Mr.&nbsp;Pauwels has held several positions, including Software Sales Manager and Director of Sales, and is currently an Executive Vice President
	responsible for our Materialise Software segment, our global sales organization and our sales offices around the world. Mr.&nbsp;Pauwels holds a Masters degree in Electro-Mechanical Engineering from KULeuven.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
<I>
	Wim Michiels
</I>
</B>
	. Wim Michiels has served as an Executive Vice President of our company since January 2011 and has been with our
	company since 1999, first as international sales manager for the prototyping service bureau, then as General Manager Asia Pacific, operating out of the Materialise Malaysia branch office. In 2006, Mr.&nbsp;Michiels returned to our headquarters to
	start a new assignment as Division Manager for our software division. In 2011, he became Executive Vice President to the company, focusing mainly on business development. Finally, Mr.&nbsp;Michiels came back to Malaysia in September 2012 to become
	the head of Materialise Malaysia Sdn. Bhd. and to further support the Asian market as corporate vice president. Mr.&nbsp;Michiels holds a Masters degree in Mechanical Engineering from KULeuven.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
<I>
	Bart Van der Schueren
</I>
</B>
	. Bart Van der Schueren has served as an Executive Vice President of our company since January 2011. Prior
	to joining Materialise, Mr.&nbsp;Van der Schueren was at KULeuven as a liaison engineer for the newly founded Materialise and established the basic research activities for the company while also founding the research activities in 3D printing at the
	KULeuven. Mr.&nbsp;Van der Schueren then went on to obtain a PhD in selective laser metal sintering. In 1995, Mr.&nbsp;Van der Schueren officially joined Materialise and ran the service bureau. Over the years, his dedication and expertise has grown
	the service bureau from a regional player to one of the most prominent additive manufacturing facilities in Europe. In 2011, Mr.&nbsp;Van der Schueren became an Executive Vice President of our company, responsible for the Materialise Manufacturing
	segment and focusing on production and engineering services. Mr.&nbsp;Van der Schueren holds a PhD in Selective Laser Metal Sintering and a Masters degree in Mechanical Engineering from KULeuven.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
<I>
	Johan Albrecht
</I>
</B>
	. Johan Albrecht has represented Alfinco BVBA as our Chief Financial Officer since August 2015. Mr.&nbsp;Albrecht
	joined Materialise from BARC NV, a global central laboratory that supports the pharmaceutical and biotech industry in the development of new drugs, where he served as Chief Financial Officer between 1989 and 2015, with responsibility for its
	worldwide financial and business reporting and control systems.&nbsp;Mr.&nbsp;Albrecht was also a member of BARC NV&#146;s executive committee and a director in its subsidiaries in Belgium, the United States, China, Australia, Singapore and South
	Africa.&nbsp;After Cerba European Lab, a network of 200 laboratories, acquired BARC NV in 2007, Mr.&nbsp;Albrecht also joined Cerba European Lab&#146;s executive committee in 2011. Prior to joining BARC NV, Mr.&nbsp;Albrecht served in various
	financial capacities with Pizzaland Benelux (United Biscuits), Applied Data Research and Minit International.&nbsp;Mr.&nbsp;Albrecht holds a postgraduate degree in corporate finance from KULeuven and a Bachelor of Science in Business Administration
	from HU Brussels University
<I>
	.
</I>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	Family Relationships
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Wilfried Vancraen and Hilde Ingelaere are spouses. Pol Ingelaere is the father of Hilde Ingelaere. No other family relationship exists between
	any members of our board of directors or senior management.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:18PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
<I>
	Compensation of Directors
</I>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Our Remuneration and Nomination Committee recommends the level of remuneration for directors. These recommendations are subject to approval by
	our board of directors and, subsequently, by our shareholders at the annual general meeting. During the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015, only the directorships of Mr.&nbsp;Vancraen, Mr.&nbsp;Leys, Ms.&nbsp;Ingelaere, Mr.&nbsp;De Lille,
	Mr.&nbsp;Vander Sloten, Mr.&nbsp;Ingels, Mr.&nbsp;Weyns and of Ms.&nbsp;Verplancke were remunerated. See &#147;&#151;Compensation of Senior Management&#148;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	- 68 -
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage71"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D120629D20F_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	for more information about the remuneration of the directorships of Mr.&nbsp;Vancraen, Mr.&nbsp;Leys and Ms.&nbsp;Ingelaere. During the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015, Mr.&nbsp;De Lille,
	Mr.&nbsp;Vander Sloten, Mr.&nbsp;Ingels, Mr.&nbsp;Weyns and Ms.&nbsp;Verplancke each received annual remuneration equal to &#128;10,000. In addition, Mr.&nbsp;De Lille, Mr.&nbsp;Vander Sloten, Mr.&nbsp;Ingels, Mr.&nbsp;Weyns and Ms.&nbsp;Verplancke
	each received a remuneration of &#128;1,250&nbsp;per physical board meeting that he or she attends and &#128;625 for each board meeting that is held via conference call (lasting more than one hour) and that he or she attends.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	In addition, the Chairman of the Audit Committee and the Chairman of the Remuneration and Nomination Committee received annual remuneration of
	&#128;7,500 and &#128;2,500 respectively. Each independent member (including the Chairman) of the Audit Committee or the Remuneration and Nomination Committee received a remuneration of &#128;1,250 for each physical committee meeting that he or she
	attends, and &#128;625 for each committee meeting that is held via conference call (lasting more than one hour) and that he or she attends. The Remuneration and Nomination Committee benchmarks directors&#146; compensation against peer companies to
	ensure that it is competitive. In addition, our board of directors sets and revises, from time to time, the rules and level of compensation for directors carrying out a special mandate or sitting on one or more of the board of directors committees
	and the rules for reimbursement of directors&#146; business-related out-of-pocket expenses.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
<I>
	Compensation of Senior Management
</I>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	We have entered into employment or consultancy agreements with each member of our senior management. The terms of these agreements are
	substantially similar, other than our agreements with Mr.&nbsp;Vancraen, Mr.&nbsp;Leys, Ms.&nbsp;Ingelaere and Alfinco BVBA, represented by Mr.&nbsp;Albrecht, the term and termination, confidentiality, non-competition and non-solicitation provisions
	of which are described separately below. These agreements generally provide for an annual base salary. In addition to the fixed remuneration components, under the terms of these agreements, members of our senior management are entitled to certain
	additional benefits (including mobile phone and director and officer liability insurance) and reimbursement of necessary and reasonable expenses. These employment or consultancy agreements with members of our senior management provide for payments
	and benefits (including upon termination of employment) that we believe are in line with customary market practice for similar companies who are operating in our industry.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	We entered into a Management Services Agreement with each of Mr.&nbsp;Vancraen, our Chief Executive Officer, Mr.&nbsp;Leys, our Executive
	Chairman, Ms.&nbsp;Ingelaere, our Executive Vice President, and Johan Albrecht as representative of Alfinco BVBA, our Chief Financial Officer, on January&nbsp;1, 2014,&nbsp;October&nbsp;24, 2013, January&nbsp;1, 2014, and 3&nbsp;July 2015
	respectively. We have agreed, pursuant to Mr.&nbsp;Leys&#146; Management Services Agreement, to appoint Mr.&nbsp;Leys as a director and chairman of our board of directors for a term of six years. Each Management Services Agreement has an indefinite
	term. Each Management Services Agreement may be terminated by us or the applicable individual with 12 months&#146; prior written notice (except for the Management Services Agreement with Johan Albrecht, where the notice period is six months) at any
	time or by us within 15 days of an uncured breach of the agreement. Under the Management Services Agreements, each of Mr.&nbsp;Vancraen, Mr.&nbsp;Leys, Ms.&nbsp;Ingelaere, Alfinco BVBA and Johan Albrecht are subject to (i)&nbsp;certain
	confidentiality obligations that will survive the termination of their respective agreements, (ii)&nbsp;certain non-compete provisions during the term of their respective Management Services Agreements and, at our option, for 12 months after the
	termination of the agreement in exchange for 100% of his or her compensation for that period if the agreement is terminated in the absence of grave fault on our part or for his or her grave fault and (iii)&nbsp;non-solicitation provisions during the
	term of the Management Services Agreement and for a period of 18 months after the termination of the agreement.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	In 2015, our senior
	management received in the aggregate total gross compensation of &#128;1.2&nbsp;million which included base salary, bonus payments, company car allowance and other benefits. This amount also includes the remuneration of the directorships of
	Mr.&nbsp;Vancraen, Mr.&nbsp;Leys and Ms.&nbsp;Ingelaere. In July 2015, we granted to certain members of our current senior management an aggregate of 18,180 warrants, exercisable for 18,180 ordinary shares at &#128;8.81&nbsp;per share, pursuant to
	the 2014 Warrant Plan. For more information regarding the 2014 Warrant Plan, see &#147;Item 10. Additional Information&#151;B. Memorandum and Articles of Association.&#148;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:18PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="4%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
<B>
	C.
</B>
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<B>
	Board Practices
</B>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	Service Contracts
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Except as described above under &#147;&#151;B. Compensation of Senior Management,&#148; we do not have service contracts with any member of our
	Board of Directors or senior management.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	Board of Directors Practices
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Decisions are generally made by our board of directors as a whole. However, decisions on certain matters may be delegated to committees of our
	board of directors to the extent permitted by law and our articles of association. The chairperson, or if he or she is prevented from doing so, the vice chairperson, chairs the meetings of our board of directors and determines the order in which the
	agenda items are discussed, the method and order of the voting, any adjournment of the discussion and passing of resolutions on individual agenda items after a due assessment of the circumstances.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	- 69 -
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage72"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D120629D20F_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Pursuant to our articles of association, our board of directors may form committees from among
	its members and charge them with the performance of specific tasks. The committees&#146; tasks, authorizations and processes are determined by our board of directors. Where permissible by law and our articles of association, important powers of our
	board of directors may also be transferred to committees.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
<I>
	Audit Committee
</I>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The Audit Committee consists of three members: Johan De Lille (Chairman), Godelieve Verplancke and J&uuml;rgen Ingels. Our board of directors
	has determined that Messrs. De Lille and Ingels and Ms.&nbsp;Verplancke are independent under Rule 10A-3 of the Exchange Act and the applicable rules of the NASDAQ Stock Market and that each of Messrs. De Lille and Ingels and Ms.&nbsp;Verplancke
	qualifies as an &#147;audit committee financial expert&#148; as defined under the Exchange Act. Ms.&nbsp;Verplancke was appointed as a member of the Audit Committee as of June, 25 2015 and replaced Hilde Ingelaere, who was previously a member of our
	audit committee in reliance on NASDAQ Stock Market&#146;s and the Exchange Act&#146;s transition rules for issuers listing in connection with an initial public offering, which permit a non-independent director to serve on the audit committee for up
	to 12 months following the initial public offering.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Our Audit Committee assists our board of directors in overseeing the accuracy and
	integrity of our accounting and financial reporting processes and audits of our consolidated financial statements, the implementation and effectiveness of an internal control system and our compliance with legal and regulatory requirements, the
	independent auditors&#146; qualifications and independence and the performance of the independent auditors.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The Audit Committee&#146;s
	duties and responsibilities to carry out its purposes include, among others:
</P>

	&nbsp;

	the establishment of procedures for (i)&nbsp;the receipt, retention and treatment of complaints we receive regarding accounting, internal accounting controls or auditing matters and (ii)&nbsp;the confidential, anonymous
	submission by our employees of concerns regarding questionable accounting or auditing matters.
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Our Audit Committee is
	entitled to review information on any point it wishes to verify, and is authorized to acquire such information from any of our employees. It is also authorized to obtain independent advice, including legal advice, if this is necessary for an inquiry
	into any matter under its responsibility. It is entitled to call on the resources that will be needed for this task. It is entitled to receive reports directly from the auditors, including reports with recommendations on how to improve our control
	processes.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
<I>
	Remuneration and Nomination Committee
</I>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Our Remuneration and Nomination Committee consists of three members: Wilfried Vancraen, Jos Vander Sloten and Johan De Lille. Mr.&nbsp;Vander
	Sloten has been appointed by our board of directors to the Remuneration and Nomination Committee as of June&nbsp;2, 2015 following the resignation of Guy Weyns. Our board of directors has determined that Mr.&nbsp;De Lille is independent under the
	applicable rules of the NASDAQ Stock Market.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;

	relating to the remuneration policy and individual remuneration packages for our board of directors and Chief Executive Officer, the appointment of directors, the Chief Executive Officer and the other members of senior management.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">

<A NAME="FIS_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE_22"></A>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The table below sets out information about the number of FTEs and fully
	dedicated consultants, which consultants included individual professionals who are registered as private entrepreneurs in Ukraine and who work exclusively with our company.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:12PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE CELLSPACING="0" CELLPADDING="0" WIDTH="84%" BORDER="0" STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" ALIGN="CENTER">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="80%">
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM" WIDTH="3%">
</TD>

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	We currently do not have a work council or trade union delegation. We have a health and safety committee
	entitled to certain information and consultation rights under Belgian law, at our Belgian headquarters. We consider our employee relations to be good and have never experienced a work stoppage.

	shares that the person has the right to acquire within 60 days of December&nbsp;31, 2015, including through the exercise of any option, warrant or other right or the conversion of any other security. These shares, however, are not included in the
	computation of the percentage ownership of any other person. Except as otherwise indicated, we believe the persons named in this table have sole voting and investment power with respect to all ordinary shares shown as beneficially owned by them,
	subject to community property laws where applicable and to the information contained in the footnotes to this table.

<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">

<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">

<TD WIDTH="4%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	(2)
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	Beneficial ownership is determined in accordance with the rules and regulations of the SEC. In computing the number of shares beneficially owned by a person and the percentage ownership of that person, we have included
	shares that the person has the right to acquire within 60 days of December&nbsp;31, 2015, including through the exercise of any option, warrant or other right or the conversion of any other security. These shares, however, are not included in the
	computation of the percentage ownership of any other person. Except as otherwise indicated, we believe the persons named in this table have sole voting and investment power with respect to all ordinary shares shown as beneficially owned by them,
	subject to community property laws where applicable and to the information contained in the footnotes to this table.
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">

<TD WIDTH="4%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	(3)
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	Consists of (i)&nbsp;5,329,664 ordinary shares held by Wilfried Vancraen, (ii)&nbsp;276,000 ordinary shares held by Hilde Ingelaere, (iii)&nbsp;40,000 ADSs held by Mr.&nbsp;Vancraen, (iv)&nbsp;14,021,612 ordinary shares
	jointly held by Mr.&nbsp;Vancraen and Ms.&nbsp;Ingelaere through Idem, a civil partnership (
<I>
	burgerlijke maatschap / soci&eacute;t&eacute; civile de droit commun
</I>
	) that is controlled and managed by Mr.&nbsp;Vancraen and Ms.&nbsp;Ingelaere, and
	(v)&nbsp;13,428,688 ordinary shares held by Ailanthus NV, which is owned and controlled by Mr.&nbsp;Vancraen and&nbsp;Ms. Ingelaere. Mr.&nbsp;Vancraen and Ms.&nbsp;Ingelaere may be deemed to share voting power and investment power over these shares.
	Does not include (i)&nbsp;1,500 warrants issued and granted to Mr.&nbsp;Vancraen or 1,500 warrants issued and granted to Ms.&nbsp;Ingelaere under the 2013 Warrant Plan, which warrants are exercisable for 6,000 ordinary shares and 6,000 ordinary
	shares, respectively, at &#128;2.14&nbsp;per share, vest 25% on a yearly basis beginning in October 2018 and expire in 2023, or (ii)&nbsp;18,180 warrants issued and granted to Mr.&nbsp;Vancraen or 18,180 warrants issued and granted to
	Ms.&nbsp;Ingelaere under the 2014 Warrant Plan, which warrants are exercisable for 18,180 ordinary shares and 18,180 ordinary shares, respectively, at &#128;8.81&nbsp;per share, vest 25% on a yearly basis beginning in October 2018 and expire in
	2024.
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="4%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	(4)
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	Ailanthus NV is owned and controlled by Hilde Ingelaere, a member of our board of directors and one of our Executive Vice Presidents, and by Wilfried Vancraen, a member of our board of directors and our Chief Executive
	Officer. Mr.&nbsp;Vancraen and Ms.&nbsp;Ingelaere may be deemed to share voting power and investment power over these shares.
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	None of our shareholders have different voting rights from other shareholders, except that as long as the Family Shareholders control,
	directly or indirectly, in the aggregate at least 20% of the voting rights attached to our ordinary shares, a majority of our directors must be appointed by our shareholders from a list of candidates proposed by the Family Shareholders. We are not
	aware of any arrangement that may, at a subsequent date, result in a change of control of our company.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	- 73 -
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage76"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D120629D20F_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	As of December&nbsp;31, 2015, there were 37 individual holders of record entered in our share
	register. The number of individual holders of record is based exclusively upon our share register and does not address whether a share or shares may be held by the holder of record on behalf of more than one person or institution who may be deemed
	to be the beneficial owner of a share or shares in our company. As of December&nbsp;31, 2015, 71.8% of our outstanding ordinary shares were held in Belgium by 34 holders of record. As of December&nbsp;31, 2015, assuming that all of our ordinary
	shares represented by ADSs are held by residents of the United States, approximately 28.2% of our outstanding ordinary shares were held in the United States by two holders of record, one of which was the Bank of New York Mellon, depositary of the
	ADSs. At such date, there were outstanding 13,325,406 ADSs, each representing one of our ordinary shares, and in the aggregate representing approximately 28.2% of our outstanding ordinary shares. The actual number of holders is greater than these
	numbers of record holders, and includes beneficial owners whose ADSs are held in street name by brokers and other nominees. This number of holders of record also does not include holders whose shares may be held in trust by other entities.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:18PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="4%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
<B>
	B.
</B>
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<B>
	Related Party Transactions
</B>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Since January&nbsp;1, 2015, there has not been, nor is there
	currently proposed, any material transaction or series of similar material transactions to which we were or are a party in which any of the members of our board of directors or senior management, holders of more than 10% of any class of our voting
	securities, or any member of the immediate family of any of the foregoing persons, had or will have a direct or indirect material interest, other than the compensation and shareholding arrangements we describe in &#147;Item 6. Directors, Senior
	Management and Employees&#148; and &#147;&#151;A. Major Shareholders,&#148; and the transactions we describe below.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	Ailanthus NV
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Ailanthus NV, a shareholder and director that is owned and controlled by Mr.&nbsp;Vancraen and Ms.&nbsp;Ingelaere, has provided several loans
	and financial leases to us for the purchase of machinery and a portion of our office and production buildings.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	We have two finance lease
	obligations with Ailanthus NV for our land and buildings in Leuven. In April 1998, we signed a finance lease agreement with Ailanthus NV to lease land and a portion of our office and production building. The lease had a term of 15 years and included
	a purchase option for the land and the building. The finance lease expired on March&nbsp;31, 2013 and the purchase option was exercised, and after administrative delays, ownership was transferred on February&nbsp;18, 2015. In October 2001, we
	entered into a finance lease agreement with Ailanthus NV to lease land and a portion of a new production building. The lease has a term of 15&nbsp;years and includes a purchase option for the land and the building. This finance lease will expire on
	September&nbsp;20, 2016. For additional information, see Note 13 to our audited consolidated financial statements.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Ailanthus NV has
	granted us several other loans at fixed interest rates between 4.23% and 5.23% with maturities between 2013 and 2025. The purpose of the loans is to finance the purchase of machines and a building in France. For additional information, see Note 13
	to our audited consolidated financial statements.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	We rent apartments on a regular basis from Ailanthus NV in order to host our employees
	from foreign subsidiaries who are visiting our headquarters in Leuven. The total amount paid to Ailanthus NV for rent in 2015 was &#128;0.17 million.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	Convertible Bonds Issuance
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	On
	October&nbsp;28, 2013 we issued to Mr.&nbsp;Leys and his spouse 1,000 convertible bonds at an issuance price of &#128;1,000&nbsp;per bond. The bonds have a maturity of seven years, bear an annual interest rate of 3.7% and can be converted into
	ordinary shares at a conversion price of &#128;1.97&nbsp;per share.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:18PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>

<TR>
<TD WIDTH="4%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">

	C.
</B>
